note_models.name: Cloze
Image Occlusion Enhanced

tmpls.name: IO Card
tmpls.qfmt:
{{#Image}}
{{Header}}
{{Question Mask}}
{{Image}}
{{Footer}}
{{/Image}}

note_models.name: Basic
Basic (and reversed card)

fields: A {{c1::cluster}} consists of a {{c2::master node}} and {{c3::a set of worker machines}} that run {{c4::containerised applications}}
The {{c1::master node}} is composed of three processes, which are {{c2::kube-apiserver}}, {{c3::kube-controller-manager}} and {{c4::kube-scheduler}}
Each individual {{c1::worker node}} in a cluster runs two processes, which are {{c2::kubelet}} and {{c3::kube-proxy}}
The {{c1::kubelet}} process in a worker machine is responsible for {{c2::communicating with the master node}}
The {{c1::master node}} is a collection of {{c2::three processes}} that run on a {{c3:: single node in a cluster}}
The {{c1::Control Plane}} was previously known as the {{c2::Kubernetes Master}}
22269b4d88cb4af58ef9ee42d8dfdb2d-oa-1
22269b4d88cb4af58ef9ee42d8dfdb2d-oa-2
22269b4d88cb4af58ef9ee42d8dfdb2d-oa-3
22269b4d88cb4af58ef9ee42d8dfdb2d-oa-4
22269b4d88cb4af58ef9ee42d8dfdb2d-oa-5
22269b4d88cb4af58ef9ee42d8dfdb2d-oa-6
22269b4d88cb4af58ef9ee42d8dfdb2d-oa-7
{{c1::The master node}} is responsible for {{c2::controlling the cluster}}
The {{c1::API Server (kube-api)}} provides {{c2::the frontend to the shared state of the cluster}} through which all other components interact
The {{c1::Scheduler (kube-scheduler)}} {{c2::assigns nodes to deployable components of our application}}
What’s the component responsible for handling node failures?
Controller Manager (kube-controller-manager)
What's the process responsible for replicating components?
Controller Manager (kube-controller-manager)
What's the process responsible for keeping track of worker nodes?
Controller Manager (kube-controller-manager)
{{c1::etcd}} is {{c2::a distributed}} {{c4::data store}} that {{c3::persistently stores the cluster configuration.}}
What’s the base command to get basic info about resources?
kubectl get <resource>
What’s the base command to get advanced info about resources?
kubectl describe <resource>
How to get advanced information about a node?
kubectl describe node <node-name>

A {{c1::ReplicationController}} or a {{c3::Deployment}} ensures that {{c2::a specified number of pod replicas are running at any one
time}}.
What's the command to make kubectl point towards a certain cluster in GKE?
gcloud container clusters get-credentials <cluster>
{{c1::Deployments}} represent {{c2::a set of multiple, identical Pods}} with {{c3::no unique identities}}

A {{c1::Deployment}} runs multiple {{c2::replicas of your application}} and
automatically {{c3::replaces any instances that fail or become unresponsive}}

{{c1::Deployments}} are managed by the {{c2::Kubernetes
Deployment controller.}}
How do you create a deployment from a docker image <image>
kubectl create deployment <name> --image=<image>
A {{c1::Service}} is a type of {{c2::resource}} that {{c3::exposes your application to external traffic.}}
The argument {{c1::--image}} of "kubectl create deployment" specifies {{c2::a docker image to deploy}}
What is the base command to expose your application to external traffic?
kubectl expose
Type the command to expose a deployment to external traffic, from port 80 to port 8080
kubectl expose deployment <deployment> --port 80 --target-port 8080
The parameter {{c1::--type LoadBalancer}} of "kubectl expose deployment" allows {{c2::to specify a service to be of type load balancer}}
We can use the {{c1::kubectl get pods}} command to {{c2::see information about our pods}}
{{c1::A pod}} is a {{c2::co-located group of containers }}
When a pod does contain multiple containers, all of them are always run on {{c1::a single worker node }}

Because all containers of a pod run under the same {{c1::Network}} and {{c2::UTS}} namespaces (we’re talking about Linux namespaces here), they all share the same {{c1::network interfaces}} and {{c2::hostname}}
Containers in the same pod share {{c1::(Linux) namespaces}}
The filesystem in containers in the same pod are {{c1::fully isolated}} from each other
What’s the base command to expose a resource as a new Kubernetes service?
Kubectl expose
What’s the base command to scale a deployment?
kubectl scale deployment <name>
What argument of “kubectl scale deployment” lets us specify the number of replicas to scale to?
—replicas <n>
The {{c1::Metadata section}} in a resource definition contains {{c2::the name}}, {{c3::namespace}}, {{c4::labels}} and other information
{{c1::The Spec section}} in a resource definition contains the description of the pod’s content such as {{c2::containers}}, {{c3::volumes}} and other data
{{c1::The Status section}} in a resource definition contains {{c2::the current information about the running resource}} as well as {{c3::the resource’s internal IP}} and other info
The {{c1::"kubectl explain <res-type>"}} command can be used to {{c2::get information about the fields that can be used inside a manifest}}
To {{c1::see the top level fields}} that can be used inside {{c2::a pod’s definition file}}, we can run {{c3::“kubectl explain pods”}}
To list and describe {{c1::the fields that can go under the metadata top-level field}} in {{c2::a pod manifest}}, we run {{c3::"kubectl explain pods.metadata"}}
To {{c1::create a resource from a manifest}}, use the {{c2::"kubectl create"}} command with {{c3::"-f <file>" parameter}}
The {{c1::kubectl create -f <file>}} command is used for {{c2::creating any resource}} from {{c3::a YAML or JSON file}}
To {{c1::get the YAML of a resource in a cluster}}, use {{c2::“kubectl get <resource-type> <name> -o yaml}}
To {{c1::get the JSON of a resource in a cluster}}, use {{c2::“kubectl get <resource-type> <name> -o json}}
To {{c1::get the YAML of a pod in a cluster}}, use {{c2::“kubectl get po <name> -o yaml}}
To {{c1::see a pod's logs}}, run {{c2::"kubectl logs <pod-name>"}}
To {{c1::see the logs of a specific container within a pod}}, run {{c2::“kubectl logs <pod-name>” -c <container>”}}
Kubectl allows to set up {{c1::port forwarding}}, which {{c2::redirects a local machine’s port into a pod’s port}}
What is the command to configure port forwarding for a pod called POD from 8888 to 8080?
Kubectl port-forward POD 8888:8080
The act of {{c1::organizing pods and all other Kubernetes objects}} is done through {{c2::labels}} and {{c3::namespaces}}
A {{c1::label}} is a(n) {{c2::arbitrary key-value pair}} that you attach to a resource, which can then filtered when selecting resources using {{c3::label selectors}}
Where in a manifest are labels specified ?
In the medatada.labels section
The {{c1::—show-labels}} parameter of {{c2::“kubectl get”}} is used to {{c3::show labels}}
To {{c1::show labels as columns}}, run {{c2::“kubectl get <resource-type>}} {{c3::-L label1,label2}}
To {{c1::add a label to a resource}}, you can run {{c2::"kubectl label <resource-type> <name> key=value}}
To {{c1::change the value of an existing label of a pod}}, run {{c2::“kubectl label po <name> key=value --overwrite}}
What’s the parameter to specify label selectors?
-l <selector>
Filter pods by label creation_date equal to manual
k get po -l creation_date=manual
To list all pods that include the env label, whatever its value is:
k get po -l env
To list all pods that do not include the env label:
k get po -l ‘!env’
What’s the label selector to select pods with the creation_method label with any value other than manual?
creation_method!=manual
What’s the label selector to select pods with the env label set to either prod or devel?
env in (prod,devel)
What’s the label selector to select pods with the env label set to any value other than prod or dev?
env notin (prod,devel)
What’s the label selector to select pods with the env label set to any value other than prod or devel?
env notin (prod,devel)
What are annotations?
They are key-value pairs that can be associated with a resource
Annotations are used primarily by ... ?
tools
Which can store more information in its value, labels or annotations ?
annotations
If you wanted to store the name of the person that created a resource, where would be a good place to put it?
In an annotation
What's the base command for annotating a resource?
> kubectl annotate
What's the command to annotate a pod called mypod with mycompany.com/someannotation set to value "foo bar"?
kubectl annotate pod mypod mycompany.com/someannotation="foo bar"
What's the standard format for annotation keys ?
mycompany.com/someannotation
What does the format mycompany.com/someannotation help prevent?
key collisions
What command would you use to see the annotations of a resource?
> kubectl describe <resource-type> <name>
What is the main use of namespaces?
To split objects into separate, non-overlapping groups
What do Kubernetes namespaces provide in terms of naming?
A scope for objects names
What do you need to do if you have two resources for which you want to use the same name?
Split them into different namespaces
How to list all namespaces in our cluster?
> k get ns
How to specify a namespace when listing resources?
Use the parameter --namespace <name>
What two lines are needed to create a namespace from a YAML file?

kind: namespace
metadata:
  name: <name>
What's the base command to create a namespace?
> k create ns
How would you create a namespace called custom-namespace?
> kubectl create namespace custom-namespace
What's the parameter for a kubectl command to take place in a specific namespace?
-n <namespace>
What should we add to a resource definition file in order to make the resource be created in a specific namespace?
metadata.namespace: <namespace>
The long form of the -n parameter can be written as ...
--namespace
By default, are pods from different namespaces isolated from each other (i.e: network-wise)
No
What's the base command to delete resources?
> k delete <res-type> <name>
What argument of "k delete" allows to delete pods using label selectors?
-l <selector>
When deleting a namespace, do resources inside the namespace get deleted?
yes
What does the --all option in "k delete" specify?
It specifies that you’re deleting all resource instances instead of specifying them by name
What argument of "k delete" specifies that we are deleting resources of all types?
> k delete all
How does k8s check if a container is still alive?
through liveness probes
How do liveness probes work?
they check if a container is still alive and restart them if not
How does a HTTP GET probe check if a container needs restarting?
It performs an HTTP GET request on the container
What are the conditions of success of a HTTP GET probe?
A response of 2xx or 3xx
What are the conditions of failure of a HTTP GET response?
Error response code or no response
How does a TCP Socket probe works?
It attempts to open a socket to your container on the specified port.
What's the condition of success of a TCP Probe?
The connection to a socket is opened successfully
What's the condition of failure of a TCP probe?
The connection to a socket fails
How does an exec probe work?
It executes an arbitrary command inside a container and checks the command's exit status code
What's the condition for success of an exec probe?
the status exit code of the command is 0
What's the condition of failure of an exec probe?
The command's exit status code is different from zero
Where in a YAML file is a liveness probe defined?

Under spec.containers, in a container's definition

Note: makes sense, since liveness probes work at the container level
What's the name of the key used to define a liveness probe in a YAML file?
livenessProbe
Where is livenessProbe defined in a YAML file?
Under spec.containers, inside a container's definition
What is the key to set a livenessProbe to be of type HTTP GET ?
httpGet
Where does httpGet go inside a YAML file?
under livenessProbe
What key under httpGet allows us to define a port?
port
What key under httpGet allows us to define a path?
path
Define an HTTP GET probe that pings the /health path at port 8029

livenessProbe:
  httpGet:
    port: 8029
    path: /health
What argument can be added to "k logs" to see the logs of containers from before restarts?
--previous
The LastState."Exit Code" shown in "k describe" is the result of what operation?
128 + signal number
What field of livenessProbe allows to configure a time after which the probe starts working?
initialDelaySeconds
What field of livenessProbe allows to configure how often to perform the probe?
periodSeconds
What field of livenessProbe allows to configure a time after which the probe, if unsuccessful, will fail
timeoutSeconds

What field of livenessProbe allows to configure the minimum consecutive successes for the probe to be
considered successful after having failed
successThreshold
What field of livenessProbe allows to configure the times of failures until K8S will restart the container?
failureThreshold
Where inside a liveness probe does the "initialDelaySeconds" key go?
livenessProbe.initialDelaySeconds
What potential problem can happen if we don't set an initial delay for a liveness probe?
That it will fail because our app isn't ready to accept being probed
Why it isn't a good idea to use an exec probe with a Java app?
Becaus startup time of JVM-based applications is costly in terms of computation
What's a Replication Controller?
A  ReplicationController  is  a  Kubernetes  resource  that  ensures  its  pods  are  always kept running.
What happens when the node hosting a pod managed by a ReplicationController crashes?
The ReplicationController creates a replacement pod in another node
What is the part of a ReplicationController that determines what pods are in the ReplicationController's scope
label selector
What is the part of a ReplicationController that determines the desired number of pods that should be running?
replica count
What is the part of a ReplicationController that determines the template to be used when creating new pod replicas?
pod template
What does the label selector in a ReplicationController do?
It determines what pods are in the ReplicationController's scope
What does the replicate count in a ReplicationController do?
It specifies the desired number of pods that should be running
What does the pod template in a ReplicationController do?
It specifies the blueprint from which new pod replicas are created
A ReplicationController is always monitoring that...
the number of running pods (that match the rc) is equal to a desired number
To create a replication controller, what value should be set for "kind:" in a YAML manifest?
ReplicationController
When creating a Replication Controller in a manifest, where should we specify the number of replicas?
spec.replicas
When creating a Replication Controller in a manifest, where should we specify the selector that matches managed pods?
spec.selector
When creating a Replication Controller in a manifest, how to specify a selector that targets pods with label "app: kubia"

spec:
  selector:
    app: kubia
Under what label do we specify the blueprint of pods to be managed by a ReplicationController or similar?
Under spec.template
A Pod is considered managed by a ReplicationController when ...
its label matches that of the RC's label selector
Where in a pod's YAML file can we find a link to the object that manages it?
In metadata.ownerReferences
What command opens an object's YAML file?
k edit <res-type> <name>
How to make sure that a ReplicationController's managed pods aren't deleted when you delete the RC?
Use the argument "--cascade=false"
What's the main advantage of a ReplicaSet over a ReplicationController?
Being able to use advanced label selectors
What's the ReplicaSet shorthand?
rs
What does the matchLabels field accept as input?
key-value pairs

What does the following accomplish?

matchLabels:
    component: redis
It matches a label with key=component and value=redis
Where in a YAML file does matchLabels go?
Under spec.selector

What's the difference between the two definitions below?

matchLabels:
    component: redis

selector: 
  app: kubia

They both have the same functionality but one is used the first one is used in the newer types of resources like ReplicaSet where as the later is used in older types of resources like ReplicationController
What is the usage of the matchExpressions field in YAML files?
To use more expressive label selectors than for example in matchLabels
What does the matchExpressions field accept as input?
A list of label-selecting expressions
Where in a YAML file do we declare matchExpressions field?
spec.selector.matchExpressions
What does each expression declared under matchExpressions  require?
a key, an operator and (depending on operator) a list of values
What operator specifies that the label's value must match one of the specified values?
In
What operator specifies that the label's value must not match any of the specified values?
NotIn
What operator specifies that the pod must include a label with the specified key?
Exists
What operator specifies that the pod must not include a label with the specified key?
DoesNotExist
What's the difference between a ReplicaSet and a DaemonSet?
The DaemonSet by default runs a single pod replica in each and every node in the cluster
If a new node is added to the cluster, what does a DaemonSet do?
It creates a pod matching its label selector in the new node
What mechanism can we use to limit the scope of the nodes to which a DaemonSet will deploy its pods?
nodeSelectors
What's the point of the Job resource?
It allows you to run a pod whose container isn’t restarted when the process running inside finishes successfully
How do we specify the behavior of a container when it finishes running?
This is done through the restartPolicy key
Where does the restartPolicy go in a YAML?
Under a container's spec
What does restartPolicy's value default to?
Always
What value of restartPolicy restarts on crash?
OnFailure
Why are you forced to change a Job's default restart policy?
Because a job is meant to run once, not indefinitely
What's the restartPolicy value that says that you should never restart a pod?
Never
What property do we need to set if we want a job to run more than once?
completions
Where is completions setting found in YAML of a Job?
spec.completions
Where is parallelism setting found in YAML of a Job?
spec.parallelism
What key do we need to set if we want a job to run several pods in parallel?
parallelism
What's the base command for changing fields of a resource through the command line?
k patch <res-type> <name>
What command can be used to change the parallelism of a job to 15
k patch job batch-job -p '{"spec": { "parallelism": 15}}'
What property allows us to limit a job's running time?
activeDeadlineSeconds
Where does the activeDeadlineSeconds property go in a Job file?
spec.activeDeadlineSeconds
What happens if a job goes longer than its activeDeadlineSeconds?
It will be terminated and marked as failed
What property allows us to specify how many times a Job should be retried before marked as failed?
backoffLimit
Where does the backoffLimit property go inside a manifest?
spec.backoffLimit
What's the default value of the backoffLimit property?
What kind of resource will execute a job at regular intervals?
CronJob
What is the key of a CronJob that allows to set intervals at which to run a job?
spec.schedule
What is the format of the 'schedule' key in a CronJob?
The same format as a cronfile
What is the name of the property to specify the definition of a job to be run by a CronJob?
jobTemplate
What's the property in CronJob that allows to specify that a job should not be started too far over the scheduled time?
startingDeadlineSeconds
What does a Service provide?
A single, constant point of entry to a group of pods providing the same service
What two things does a service have that don't change while the service exists?
IP address and port
What mechanism is used to define what pods are managed by a service?
label selectors
In a Service's manifest, under what property do we define the port and targetPort?
spec.ports
Are Cluster IPs accessible from outside the cluster?
No
How to execute a command inside a pod?
k exec <pod-name> -- command
What's the use of "--" after "k exec <pod> ?
It makes sure that arguments after the "--" are used for the command to execute, and not for kubectl
What property should be set to make all requests by a certain client to be redirected to the same pod every time?
sessionAffinity
What value of SessionAffinity should be set to use IP Address when determining which pod should answer a request?
ClientIP
What is session affinity?
It's a way of making traffic from a specific client to be answered by a specific node
Where in a Pod's manifest can we give a name to a port?
In a containers'definition, under ports.containerPort
Where can we define ports for a container?
In the container's definition, in the ports property
Where do we use the name of named ports in a service's manifest?
in the targetPort property
What's the advantage of naming ports in a Pod's manifest?
If we use the port's name in the Service definition, we can later change the port in the pod without changing the service
Where in a Pod can we find the IP address of existing services?
In the environment variable <SERVICE_NAME_HOST>
Where in a Pod can we find the port of existing services?
In the environment variable <SERVICE_NAME_PORT>
At which point does a Pod's environment variables pointing to services get initialized?
When the pod is created
Pods are automatically configured to use kube-dns through means of what?
through a configuration file called /etc/resolv.conf
Instead of accessing a service though its IP, you can access it through its?
Fully Qualified Domain Name (FQDN)
The FQDN of a service is composed of three parts:
<service-name>.<namespace>.<cluster-domain-suffix>
What's the resource that sits between a service and the pods it links to?
Endpoints
What's an Endpoints resource?
A list of IP addresses and ports exposing a service.
To create a service with manually managed endpoints, what resources do you need to create?
both a Service and an Endpoints resource.
To create a service with manually managed endpoints, both Service and Endpoints resources need to have the same...
metadata.name
A service with manually managed endpoints can be used to ...
point to an external, load balanced service
In an Endpoints manifest, what is the subsets property?
It's the set of addresses and ports that comprise a service
What type should a Service be so that the Service serves as an alias for an external service?
type ExternalName
Where in a manifest do we specify the type of a service?
spec.type
In a Service that serves as an alias for an external Service, what should we put under spec.externalName?
The FQDN of the external service
In which type of Service does traffic received on each cluster node gets redirected to the underlying Service?
NodePort service type
What type of Service makes itself available through a load balancer provisioned by the cloud infrastructure Kubernetes is running on?
Load Balancer service type
What's a NodeType service type?
It's a Service where traffic going to a certain port in each node cluster is redirected to the Service
What manifest property of a NodePort service is used to bind to a port in each node cluster?
spec.nodePort
When using a NodeBalancer service, a connection received on the nodePort of node X, does it get routed to a pod in node X by default?
No
What's a potential problem with sending all client requests to a single node through a NodePort service?
That the node fails, in which case the client won't be able to access the service anymore
To avoid the problem of NodePort Services where one node failing denies client access, what can we do?
Put a load balancer that distributes traffic between the healthy nodes
What is the requirement to create a LoadBalancer service?
That the cloud provider the infrastructure runs on supports provisioning a LoadBalancer
What happens if you don't specify a node port in a NodePort or LoadBalancer service?
Kubernetes chooses one for you
What extra configuration does NodePort services require over LoadBalancer services on GKE
NodePort services require the creation of a firewall rule to open the desired port
Why don't different requests from the same browser to a LoadBalanced service reach a different node ?
Because browsers use keep-alive connections (so it's the same connection)
A LoadBalancer-type  service  is  a extension of  {{c2::NodePort}}  service  with  an additional {{c1::infrastructure-provided load balancer}}
What's the main advantage of using Ingresses instead of Load Balancer service?
Ingresses require only one load balancer, whereas Load Balancer services require a load balancer each
What in an HTTP request to an Ingress determines which service a request is forwarded to?
The host and the path
Where does an Ingress route incoming HTTP requests?
To the corresponding Service
For an Ingress resource to work, what is needed?
An Ingress controller running on the cluster
Ingress controllers on cloud providers require the Ingress to point to what kind of service?
NodePoint
In what property of an Ingress do we specify a series of rules of how to deal with requests to specific domains and paths?
In spec.rules
What does spec.rules property in Ingress hold?
A series of host rules to configure to which service we will send requests pointing to certain domains and paths
Where do we put host rules in an Ingress manifest?
Under spec.rules
Where do we specify a host in an Ingress manifest?
Under spec.rules
The http property under spec.rules in an Ingress is what?
It's a list of http selectors pointing to backends
Where does the paths property go in an ingress?
Under rules.http
What is the paths property in an Ingress?
A collection of paths that map requests to backends
Under which property do we define a backend service in an Ingress manifest?
Under paths, inside a path definition
Under which property do we define the backend property in an Ingress manifest?
Under paths, inside a path definition
Where does the path property go in an Ingress manifest?
It's one of the possible items inside the paths property
What is the value of path inside an Ingress manifest?
A path after a domain such as "/'
Where does serviceName go inside an Ingress manifest?
Under paths[*].backend
Where does servicePort  go inside an Ingress manifest?
Under paths[*].backend
What is the serviceName property inside a path's definition in an Ingress manifest?
The name of a service to which a request will be redirected
What is the servicePort property inside a path's definition in an Ingress manifest?
The port of a service to which a request will be redirected
Requests to what domain & path are being redirected?
kubia.example.com at path /
What does this do?
It redirects requests to kubia.example.com at path / to a service called kubia-nodeport at port 80
How to easily generate the yaml necessary to create any resource?
Create the resource with "k run [...]" with parameters --dry-run -o yaml > resource.yaml
What does the  --restart=Never flag in "kubectl run" do?
The --restart=Never flag makes this a standalone pod rather than a deployment
What does the -it parameter allow when executing a command using "kubectl run"
To see the output of the command
How to watch for changes in a pod?
In "k get", add -w argument
What's the difference between "k create" and "k apply" ?
K apply can be used to update a resource, whereas create is used to create it
What should we use to solve the problem of Pods not being ready right away to accept requests?
Use readiness probes
What does a readiness Probe do?
If periodically probes a Pod and determines whether the pod is ready to accept requests
What's the main different between liveness Probes and readiness Probes?
Contrary to liveness probes, readiness probes don't kill a failing container
If a pod's readiness probe fails, what happens that makes it unreachable by a client?
The pod is removed from the Endpoints object pointed to by the Service
Why does each container in a pod have their own, isolated, filesystem?
Because the filesystem comes from the container's image
Storage volumes are defined inside the manifest of a {{c1::Pod}}
Storage volumes share the same lifecycle as the {{c1::pod}} in which they are defined
What does it mean that Storage volumes share the same lifecycle as a pod?
It means that a volume is created and destroyed with the pod
After a pod fails and is replaced, can the new pod see the contents of the volume used by the old pod?
No
After a container restarts, can the new container see the contents of the volume used by the old container?
yes
a  volume’s  contents  will  persist  across  {{c1::container}} restarts
What's the hostPath volume type?
It's used for mounting directories from the worker node's filesystem
What's the gitRepo volume type?
A volume initialized by initializing the contents of a Git repo
What's the nfs volume type?
A NFS share
What makes a hostPath volume be of type of persistent storage?
Its contents aren't tied to the Pod's lifesystem
What volume is created by initializing the contents of a Git repo?
gitRepo
What volume is created from a NFS share?
nfs
What volume starts out as an empty directory?
emptyDir
What's the emptyDir volume?
It's a volume that it's initialized as an empty directory
To create a volume, what property we need to put in a Pod?
spec.volumes
What property identifies a volume in a Pod manifest?
name
What property identifies a volume's type in a Pod's manifest?
the name of the volume type as a property name
What's the property to mount volumes in a container?
volumeMounts
What property identifies a volume mount?
name
What property under volumeMounts specifies a path in which to mount a volume?
mountPath
What property allows us to specify whether a volume mount is read only or not?
readOnly
By default, where does the emptyDir volume get created?
On the node hosting your pod
Why an emptyDisk being created on the disk of the hosting node can lead to performance issues?
Because it depends on the type of disk of the worker node
What property allows us to make an emptyDir volume be created in memory?
A gitRepo volume is a type of {{c1::emptyDir}} volume initially populated with {{c2::the contents of a Git repository.}}
Does a gitRepo volume stay synced with the git repository it points to?
No
Why is it important to set a value to the gitRepo.directory property?
To prevent our repo to be cloned to the default directory selected by Git
What's a sidecar container?
A sidecar container is a container that adds some functionality to the main container of the pod
Why is hostPath unreliable for use in regular pods?
Because the volume only exists on the node it's hosted on
When should you use hostPath volumes?
only if you need to read or write system files on the node
{{c4::PersistentVolumes}} are consumed by pods through {{c3::PersistentVolumeClaims}}.
What are PersistentVolumes?
It's a storage resource that is not tired the lifecycle of a pod
What's the ReadWriteOnce access mode?
What do we call the access mode for a volume where a single client can access for reading and writing
What's the ReadOnlyMany access mode?
What do we call the access mode for a volume where multiple clients can access for reading only?
The {{c1::persistentVolumeReclaimPolicy}} in a PersistentVolume determines {{c2::what happens to the persistent volume when released from its claim}}
How to add a PersistentVolume to a namespace?
You can't. PVs are cluster-level resources and don't belong to any namespace
Why are PersistentVolumeClaims not defined at the level of a Pod?
Because we want them to stay available even if the pod is rescheduled
What does it mean that a pod is rescheduled?
It's deleted and a new one is created
In a PVC, what does spec.resources mean?
It's the minimum amount of resources the volume should have
{{c1::RWO}} stands for {{c2::ReadWriteOnce}}
{{c1::ROX}} stands for {{c2::ReadOnlyMany}}
{{c1::RWX}} stands for {{c2::ReadWriteMany}}
RWO, ROX, and RWX pertain to the number of {{c1::worker nodes}} that can use the volume at the same time, not to the number of {{c1::pods}}!
What does it mean that a PersistentVolume has status Bound?
It means that it has been claimed by a PersistentVolumeClaim
What does it mean that a PersistentVolume has status Available?
It means that a PersistentVolumeClaim can claim it
Where can we see by which Claim is a PersistentVolume claimed?
> k get pv
To use a PersistentVolumeClaim inside a pod, what do you need to do?
Reference the PersistentVolumeClaim it by name inside the pod's volume
What does the Recycle reclaim policy consist of?
The Recycle policy deletes the volume's contents and makes it available for reclaim
What does the Delete reclaim policy consist of?
It deletes the volume
What's the reclaim policy that deletes the volume’s contents and makes the volume available to be claimed again?
Recycle
What's the reclaim policy that deletes the volume?
Delete
How to prevent a volume with a Delete reclaim policy from losing data when its lifecycle end?
Change it to Retain beforehand
fabf8c4ee98b4785b76d9c5c8c21d085-oa-1
fabf8c4ee98b4785b76d9c5c8c21d085-oa-2
fabf8c4ee98b4785b76d9c5c8c21d085-oa-3
fabf8c4ee98b4785b76d9c5c8c21d085-oa-4
fabf8c4ee98b4785b76d9c5c8c21d085-oa-5
What property needs to be set to reference a StorageClass in a PersistentVolumeClaim?
spec.storageClassName
What happens if you create a PersistentVolumeClaim without specifying the storageClassName attribute?
If supported, a Disk will be created for you of the default StorageClass
Explicitly set storageClassName to {{c1::""}} if you want the PVC to {{c2::use a pre-provisioned PersistentVolume.}}
What argument of "k rollout undo" allows to to specify a revision to rollback to?
--to-revision=<rev-number>
What's "k rollout history" used for?
To view previous rollout revisions and configurations.
What argument of "k rollout history" allows to select a revision to check?
--revision=<rev-number>
To follow the logs of a resource, add which parameter to the "k logs" command"?
-f
See the rollout history of a deploment called deploy
k rollout history deploy deploy
To override an ENTRYPOINT, what property should we set?
Inside a container -> spec.command
To override CMD, what property should we set?
Inside a container -> spec.args
What's the format of the args property that replaces CMD?
What's the format of the command property that replaces ENTRYPOINT?
["command"]
Can the list of environment variables of a container be updated after the pod is created?
No
What property of a container is used to define environment variables?
env
A simple environment variable is defined as a pair of properties called what?
name + value
What syntax should we use to reference a previously defined environment variable in a manifest?
$(ENV_VAR)
In what resource does the backoffLimit property go?
Jon
What happens if a referenced ConfigMap doesn’t exist when you create a pod?
The container referencing the CM fails to start until the CM is created,but the other contaioners start normally
How to make a container start even if the ConfigMap it references doesn't exist?
By setting optional to true under configMapKeyRef
On creating a config map, what argument allows to insert from file?
--from-file
On creating a config map, what argument allows to insert from a string?
--from-literal
On creating a config map, what argument allows to insert from file, giving a custom key to the file?
--from-file=<key>=<file>
If no key is specified in --from-file argument to "k create configmap", what's the key's name?
The full name of the file
What attribute allows to import all env variables from a ConfigMap in one go?
envFrom
What property under envFrom allows to add a prefix to all imported variables?
prefix
What property under envFrom allows to specify a config map?
configMapRef
What property under configMapRef allows to specify the name of a config map from which to import?
name
Is CONFIG-BAR a valid config map environment variable?
No, because of the dash
A {{c2::configMap volume}} will expose each entry of the ConfigMap as {{c1::a file}}
27007f291a7744ffa53cbf3d9d9fdb96-oa-1
27007f291a7744ffa53cbf3d9d9fdb96-oa-2
27007f291a7744ffa53cbf3d9d9fdb96-oa-3
27007f291a7744ffa53cbf3d9d9fdb96-oa-4
27007f291a7744ffa53cbf3d9d9fdb96-oa-5
27007f291a7744ffa53cbf3d9d9fdb96-oa-6
When specifying individual entries in a configMap volume, you need to set {{c1::the filename for each individual entry}}, along with {{c2::the entry’s key}}
When mounting a directory, what happens to the existing files in that directory?
They are inaccessible for as long as the mount exists
Why it's probably a bad idea to mount a directory to /etc?
Because /etc contains many important files which will be inaccessible when /etc is mounted
How to mount individual ConfigMap entries as files without hiding other files in the directory?
In volumeMounts property, mount to a file instead of mounting to a directory
What property of a configMap volume allows to set file permissions for all imported files?
defaultMode
What's the syntax of configMap.defaultMode ?
A value between 0 and 0777
What's the default value of configMap.defaultMode ?
When mounting to a file, what property allows to to specify the file in the ConfigMap from which we are importing?
subPath
